column1: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the most common cancer of the thyroid gland.

Exposure may occur from: - High-dose external radiation treatments to the neck, especially during childhood, used to treat childhood cancer or some non-cancerous childhood conditions - Radiation exposure from nuclear plant disasters Radiation given through a vein (through an IV) during medical tests and treatments does not increase the risk of developing thyroid cancer.
Thyroid cancer usually begins as a small lump (nodule) in the thyroid gland.
While some small lumps may be cancer, most (90%) thyroid nodules are harmless and are not cancerous.
This test helps determine if the lump is cancerous.
After the surgery, most patients receive radioactive iodine, which is usually taken by mouth.
After surgery or radioactive iodine, patients will need to take medication called levothyroxine for the rest of their life.
Most patients who had thyroid cancer need to have a blood test every 6 to 12 months to check thyroid hormone levels.
More than 95% of adults with this cancer survive at least 10 years.
